posts.name: Ishmaam Khan
posts.cooked: I just came across x.com and Signal Desktop Leaves Message Decryption Key in Plain Sight. It seems like Signal stores encryption key in plain text on desktop client(s)? It‚Äôs also been known for a long time and I don‚Äôt understand why there‚Äôs no initiative to refactor it.

posts.name: Derek Morr
posts.cooked: The argument is that if someone has physical access to your device, then it‚Äôs really game over. Having said that, I think there are reasonable things the signal team could do to improve desktop app security, especially against other malicious software on the device.

posts.name: Ishmaam Khan
posts.cooked: The second part of the response is the exactly the reason why they need to improve it. I‚Äôm honestly surprised more people don‚Äôt know about this and that the Signal team simply isn‚Äôt interested in working on it.

posts.name: Nix (N1X)
posts.cooked:
Hey community,

As a long time fellow user of Signal, a donator and Beta Tester, I don‚Äôt believe on most of the news we got against our privacy, and a day ago a recently flaw involving our desktop version of Signal got attention. It has been discovered and the results of the hack, spread on Twitter (X). It‚Äôs about a copy of the signal data folder moved to a new MacOS‚Äôs VM having Signal desktop installed from a scratch.

Have anyone heard about it? What the hell is it? According to the hack, Signal don‚Äôt even report or alert users of such behaviour.

I read it the whole text, and seems to have some logic behind it, but I‚Äôm not sure about the source.

Comments?

Eddie

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Ongoing discussion here Signal stores encryption key in plain text on desktop client(s)?

tl;dr: it‚Äôs 1. Nothing new. It‚Äôs been around for years. And 2. Not a hack. All they did was take the Signal data file on their own computer for which they have physical access and the password, copied it, moved it to a VM, linked the VM to their mobile, and could see the conversation history.

This is no different than having physical or remote access to a desktop OS with Signal installed‚Ä¶and opening Signal to read messages.

THERE IS NO HACK!!!

from Signal-Desktop/CONTRIBUTING.md at main ¬∑ signalapp/Signal-Desktop ¬∑ GitHub

The staging environment

Sadly, this default setup results in no contacts and no message history, an entirely empty application. But you can use the information from your production install of Signal Desktop to populate your testing application!

First, exit both production and development apps (In macOS - literally quit the apps). Second, find your application data in the appData directory:

  • macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/Signal
  • Linux: ~/.config/Signal
  • Windows 10: C:\Users\<YourName>\AppData\Roaming\Signal

Now make a copy of this production data directory in the same directory (a sibling of the Signal directory), and call it Signal-development. Now start up the development version of the app as normal, and you‚Äôll see all of your contacts and messages!

and this is for years!!!

posts.name: Derek Morr
posts.cooked:
Signal absolutely should implement sandboxing and better database key storage when the host OS supports it. But calling this a ‚Äúhack‚Äù is not fair.

While I‚Äôm glad this issue is getting more attention, it‚Äôs being way overblown on social media. I fear it‚Äôs just going to push more people onto less secure messaging apps. The best thing would be for Signal to quickly fix the issue, release a statement, and move on.

posts.name: Moritz Tim W.
posts.cooked:
derekmorr:

The argument is that if someone has physical access to your device, then it‚Äôs really game over.

I really dislike this argument because based on that you might as well just have no on-device security. The harder it is to get the key the less likely it is that someone, who gained access to your device, is going to go through the effort of stealing it.
Besides that, you don‚Äôt need physical access to the device.

epimazzo:

As a long time fellow user of Signal, a donator and Beta Tester, I don‚Äôt believe on most of the news we got against our privacy, and a day ago a recently flaw involving our desktop version of Signal got attention. It has been discovered and the results of the hack, spread on Twitter (X). It‚Äôs about a copy of the signal data folder moved to a new MacOS‚Äôs VM having Signal desktop installed from a scratch.

Have anyone heard about it? What the hell is it? According to the hack, Signal don‚Äôt even report or alert users of such behaviour.

I think there are two issues at play here. One is that Signal doesn‚Äôt securely encrypt their database and doesn‚Äôt encrypt stored media at all on desktop. That has been known for years, but that doesn‚Äôt make it less problematic. If this were completely out of their threat model why would they use SQLCipher at all? The threat model doesn‚Äôt really match the implementation. Of course they could say that the initially intended to do it but didn‚Äôt due to reliability issues but afaik they don‚Äôt.

The second issue is that a cloned desktop session will just silently live forever and the user is never informed except for some decryption failed messages. This is imo the bigger issue and one that I haven‚Äôt seen publicly documented so far.

Calling this a hack or a reason to move away from Signal is of course nonsense. This is not a hack of Signal in the traditional sense where a remote party could access your chats. For that they would need to hack your computer, if that is indeed easy then you have got bigger issues. In the worst case this is a documentation issue in Signals threat model or a security relevant bug in their implementation. But not what one usually considers a ‚Äúhack‚Äù.

In general I think it‚Äôs bad that any discussion of Signals potential flaws is stifled under the pretense that it would lead people to go for less secure alternatives. Secure messaging is not done and Signal isn‚Äôt perfect.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Typically the OS should be providing more protections if you want it to be more secure. Signal could improve a bit by using the keystore explicitly, but as long as the OS doesn‚Äôt measurely protect against exploitation and physical access or malware v√≠a sandboxing, it‚Äôs almost a loosing game.

mangold:

The second issue is that a cloned desktop session will just silently live forever and the user is never informed except for some decryption failed messages.

I can‚Äôt confirm this on Linux. I copied my Signal folder (~./var/app/‚Ä¶) to an new Linux install on a different computer. I was able to read all my messages up to the time of the copy. However, I cannot receive any messages that were sent afterwards.

I

derekmorr:

The argument is that if someone has physical access to your device, then it‚Äôs really game over. Having said that

I completely disagree about the safety precautions. There are always security loopholes that allow an attacker to access user data. Software with security-relevant data must protect itself against this. Nobody will use KeePass without an additional password. There have been many cases of account theft because FileZilla refused to protect account data for years. In the meantime, the developers have changed their minds and introduced password protection.

Signal should:

  • Encrypt chat history and build in security checks that tie the database to the device.
  • There should be a clear indication that the Signal desktop app does not currently protect content. This is important for people who live in dictatorships and whose lives may depend on it. No information can be found, neither on the support page nor on the download page.

My suggestion: As a quick measure, the download page should contain appropriate security information.

Piggeldy:

I can‚Äôt confirm this on Linux. I copied my Signal folder (~./var/app/‚Ä¶) to an new Linux install on a different computer. I was able to read all my messages up to the time of the copy. However, I cannot receive any messages that were sent afterwards.

So the messages were not delivered at all? To none of the two copies?
In my case they were always delivered to one of them (which makes sense given how Signal works).

Piggeldy:

Encrypt chat history and build in security checks that tie the database to the device.

But I don‚Äôt want to tie the database to my device. My PC changes all the time and I don‚Äôt want to lose my message history just because I changed the processor, RAM or other hardware.

What I would agree to: Encrypting all Signal data with a passphrase and store the passphrase in kwallet or whatever key management system the os or electron support.

mangold:

So the messages were not delivered at all? To none of the two copies?

The authenticated installation on my old notebook continues to receive messages. The cloned version on my new notebook only shows the chats up to the time of the copy.

Wopfi:

My PC changes all the time and I don‚Äôt want to lose my message history just because I changed the processor, RAM or other hardware.

Valid point. Having an encrypted database could be a safe way to move the complete chat history to a new device without tying the database to the hardware.
In my short test, I didn‚Äôt find an option to re-activate my cloned install on the new device. Therefore, I have to delete the data copy and reinitialize with losing the chat history.

posts.cooked: What happens when the original session goes offline? Will the copy start receiving messages?

Quite disappointing to see Signal not commenting on the matter. They were pretty quick at debunking baseless disinformation spread by Durov and Musk but they are refraining on commenting on this issue, even after extensive social media chatter, forum threads, reddit posts, and even a Forbes article. They are not even participating in the pull request seeking to address this Protect database encryption key with Electron `safeStorage` API by pl4nty ¬∑ Pull Request #6849 ¬∑ signalapp/Signal-Desktop ¬∑ GitHub. It‚Äôs likely that many user are uninstalling Signal out of confusion, thinking the app is somehow compromised.

link_counts.title: Protect database encryption key with Electron `safeStorage` API by pl4nty ¬∑ Pull Request #6849 ¬∑ signalapp/Signal-Desktop ¬∑ GitHub

posts.cooked:
A couple of questions:

It seems that Signal is using the MacOS keychain for something, but it‚Äôs not to store the decryption key of the local desktop msg database. Does anyone know what it‚Äôs being used for?

Also, does anyone know the reason why Signal doesn‚Äôt store the decryption key in the keychain, like whatsapp does?

Thanks!

fancy_title: Signal stores encryption key in plain text on desktop client(s)?
title: Signal stores encryption key in plain text on desktop client(s)?

accepted_answer.name: Whatnoww
accepted_answer.excerpt:
Devs have mentioned a workaround here:

Beta feedback for the upcoming Desktop 7.17 release

Thanks for highlighting this scenario, and sorry for the trouble it has caused. In future releases we will indicate which secret store was used to encrypt the key, to at least help debugging the issue.

If you are unable to use the same secret store across desktop environments and you are OK not encrypting the database key, you could attempt the following: decrypt the key, keep the plaintext key in config.json, e.g. { key: "plaintextKey" }, and always start the application with the command line args --password-store=‚Äùbasic‚Äù. Sorry for any incovenience!

And thank you for reporting those errors when you click ‚ÄúCopy error and quit‚Äù, etc. We have fixes coming for those.

For posteriority‚Äôs sake, seems like the entire database is now encrypted properly. Nothing is plaintext. Huge success for everyone that uses Signal that had this contention!

Thanks to everyone that pushed for this fixed, followed it, never gave up, etc.

Not everything went perfectly but ultimately Signal is now a more secure app especially on Desktop.
